comment_data.body:
I think it can be better described if you make it a table containing severity -> text mappings: `sign = { text = { ERROR = 'E', WARNING = 'W' ... } }`.

I think it should be considered a breaking change if the sign define API for these signs is removed. But perhaps one that is acceptable if Neovim wants to further encourage extmark usage over legacy signs?

comment_data.body:
The default should also be smarter than replacing the whole table. For example, if a user only wants to change the sign text for errors but use the default values for the other severities, they might use:

```lua
vim.diagnostic.config({ signs = { text = { [vim.diagnostic.severity.ERROR] = 'X' } } })
```

but this would cause warnings, information, and hints to display as `U`.

```lua
local text = opts.signs.text or {}
local default = { [vim.diagnostic.severity.ERROR] = 'E', ... }

  if not text[k] then
    text[k] = v
  end
end
```

and then use this local `text` table rather than `opts.signs.text` when creating the extmark.

comment_data.body:
This modifies the `opts` table, which we do not want. Better to assign to a new `local` table.

Also, maybe it's just me but I find this `iter` block to be pretty opaque. A simple for loop (as I suggested originally) might be a win here for readability.

```lua
local text = {}
for k in pairs(vim.diagnostic.severity) do
  if opts.sign.text[k] then
    text[k] = opts.sign.text[k]
  elseif type(k) == 'string' and not text[k] then
    text[k] = string.sub(k, 1, 1):upper()
  end
end
```

comment_data.body:
In any case, `{ unpack(M.severity, 1, 4) }` is too clever, it's not at all obvious what this does or why `1` and `4` are used, and makes an assumption on what the values of each of the severities are. Writing out

```lua
{
  [vim.diagnostic.severity.ERROR] = 'E',
  [vim.diagnostic.severity.WARN] = 'W',
  [vim.diagnostic.severity.INFO] = 'I',
  [vim.diagnostic.severity.HINT] = 'H',
}
```

is more verbose, but much more clear. There's no reason to be terse here if it sacrifices clarity.

comment_regular_data.body:
Looks like this removes the option to have an empty text but colored numbers. Before this was possible with:

```
sign define DiagnosticSignError text= texthl= linehl= numhl=ErrorMsg
sign define DiagnosticSignWarn text= texthl= linehl= numhl=WarningMsg
sign define DiagnosticSignInfo text= texthl= linehl= numhl=Underlined
sign define DiagnosticSignHint text= texthl= linehl= numhl=Underlined
```

Any chance to get this back? Also out of curiosity - what's the motivation for the change?  I thought sign's are internally now extmarks based anyways

>  Also out of curiosity - what's the motivation for the change? I thought sign's are internally now extmarks based anyways

Only motivation I could think of is that since we (Neovim) consider `sign_define/place()` "legacy", we should no longer use it. But yes, this PR only changes the configuration interface. Internally, this makes no difference.

> Looks like this removes the option to have an empty text but colored numbers. Before this was possible with:
> 
> ```
> sign define DiagnosticSignError text= texthl= linehl= numhl=ErrorMsg
> sign define DiagnosticSignWarn text= texthl= linehl= numhl=WarningMsg
> sign define DiagnosticSignInfo text= texthl= linehl= numhl=Underlined
> sign define DiagnosticSignHint text= texthl= linehl= numhl=Underlined
> ```
> 
> Any chance to get this back?

We can support this, `nvim_buf_set_extmark` allows both `number_hl_group` and `line_hl_group` to be set. I'll add this to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26555 as well.

> Also out of curiosity - what's the motivation for the change? I thought sign's are internally now extmarks based anyways

At least one benefit is that it further consolidates the diagnostic configuration interface into `vim.diagnostic.config()`.

This PR is a breaking change indeed. It affects plugins that get diagnostic signs by `sign_getdefined`, such as neo-tree. 

Should we:

* Define these signs both in `vim.diagnostic.config` and `sign_define` as a user workaround.
* Immediately update these plugins as plugin authors.
* Revert this PR as neovim core developers? (Don't see the benefit of this PR)

 I don't know what to do next.

> Don't see the benefit of this PR

1. Only a unique diagnostic configuration interface is provided. Reduce mental load. no longer needs to write those sign_define codes in config.
2. numhl linehl allows customization.
3. If you use head neovim there is nothing to complain about.

> Define these signs both in vim.diagnostic.config and sign_define as a user workaround.

Yes, on an user's side who are gratefully adventurous to try out 0.10 nightly this is a good solution/workaround. [I also did this too](https://github.com/wookayin/dotfiles/commit/a5336885b515b4849f843c87832628271aad264b) and neotree works fine. It's just that the plugin hasn't yet catched up with the change of a development version.

> I don't know what to do next.

With the both config written, neotree should work fine for the time being (until the downstream plugins get updated to read the diagnostic sign information configured via `vim.diagnostic.config { signs = ... }`). I encourage you to file an issue in neotree so that the plugin can support the new features soon.

That being said, I think it's at least worth considering to have some kind of backward compatibility by letting `vim.diagnostic.config` internally define signs `DiagnosticSignError`, etc. (if they didn't exist) w.r.t the `text`, `texthl`, `numhl` settings provided. Signs is a feature (although being kind of deprecated) that still exists in (neo)vim, and the internal implementation is through extmark, there is a valid reason to make `vim.diagnostic` work nicely with the already existing concept. Also because of the name `vim.diagnostic`.**`signs`**.

I'm not complaining about it but pointing out it, following HEAD means I'm prepared for breaking changes but not waiving the right to discuss. The difference between the two is thinking or not.

And I just found that @gpanders commented the news about this change should be in `news-breaking` instead of `news-changed`, I think so too.

Depending on how you handle this change, I don't think you realize this is a breaking change, and should not make change arbitrarily even for HEAD users.

>With the both config written, neotree should work fine for the time being. I encourage you to file an issue in neotree so that the plugin can support the new features soon.

I'm planning to make PRs for these plugins that I used and have issues with this change(you can see it above), but I'm not sure if will there be any subsequent changes. So there are these comments.
@rockyzhang24  I don't want to pay attention to your comment. Don't make irrelevant comments here. Please learn to be polite before speaking.

The problem is that the incompatibility breaks the plugin. I see little benefit in maintaining compatibility here. sign_define is just an initial compromise. Providing a unified interface makes everything easier. If only the plugin is broken. Then the plugin should be able to judge by use vim.version.

> That being said, I think it's at least worth considering to have some kind of backward compatibility by letting `vim.diagnostic.config` internally define signs `DiagnosticSignError`, etc. (if they didn't exist) w.r.t the `text`, `texthl`, `numhl` settings provided. Signs is a feature (although being kind of deprecated) that still exists in (neo)vim, and the internal implementation is through extmark, there is a valid reason to make `vim.diagnostic` work nicely with the already existing concept. Also because of the name `vim.diagnostic`.**`signs`**.

Thanks @ofseed for bringing this issue up. I agree with @wookayin's suggestion. I take user experience very seriously and want to avoid unexpected breakages as much as possible.

I expect that not all uses of `sign_define` for diagnostic signs are just in plugins, many users likely have their own configurations. The breaking change is documented in `news.txt` and will be mentioned in the release notes, but even still we have a [policy](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/MAINTAIN.md#deprecating-and-removing-features) for breaking changes for this exact reason.

I will make a follow up PR that gracefully handles the existence of diagnostic signs created by the user with `sign_define` and shows a deprecation warning. As per our own guidelines, this warning will exist for one full release cycle, after which using `vim.diagnostic.config()` will be the _only_ allowed method.
